data.title: Dennis Coffey
data.meta_description: Explore the Red Bull Music Academy archive, tracing the global music institutionâs more than 20-year history
data.text:
(music: Dennis Coffey â âGetting It Onâ / applause)

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, thatâs one of your solo recordings, but before you were a soloist you were doing session work. You actually started at quite a young age, is that correct?

Dennis Coffey

Yes, also Chuck D was here last week and he sampled that âGetting It Onâ record you just heard, without my knowledge, of course [laughter). So, Iâm sitting in the studio, saying, âLet me hear whatâs going on,â and I hear this track and say: âI donât remember getting paid for this session.â I talked to him at the R&B Foundation gala in Philadelphia about four weeks ago, because that was the first time I had a chance to talk to him, and he said, âWe didnât get paid either. I thought you might sue the company and get us some money too.â So, thatâs the story for the first time I remember myself being sampled.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Your roots obviously pre-date that. If we can go back, tell us how you got started playing guitar. Youâre from Detroit, is that correct?

Dennis Coffey

From Detroit, and I had a couple of cousins in the upper peninsula of Michigan, and they played guitar and showed me some chords. I was fascinated with the guitar, and my mom told me I could name every song on the radio when I was three. Somehow, I had a real affinity for music and I started practicing, practiced eight hours a day when I wasnât going to school in the summer. I ended up contracting and playing on my first session when I was 15, got some friends from high school and had to get one guy who could drive, because we werenât old enough to drive to the session [laughs]. It was great, I heard myself on the radio when I was 15, took a couple of solos and I was hooked from then on, so I just kept practicing. I still consider myself a student of music, itâs still out there and every day I try to do something different. I still love it.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, you started in the â50s when you were a teenager, the birth of the rock & roll era.

Dennis Coffey

I was in the middle of it, so as things were evolving, the crowd that I hung around with in Detroit, we were playing teen clubs working two night a week. We were 16, 17-years old and we were getting paid and doing gigs already.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Describe that scene, because before you were old enough to get into bars and start doing gigs, you left to join the military, is that correct?

Dennis Coffey

I wasnât old enough to go from the teen clubs to the bars, so I volunteered for the draft, spent a couple of years in the paratroopers, jumping out of airplanes, which seemed like a good idea at the time, but Iâm not so sure it was. I was doing gigs at the same time at night, and I almost got court-martialed, because they were all lined up for doing maneuvers one day and I pulled up in a cab with my guitar. So, I had to join another unit, where I could play at night while still being in the service. So, I was recording with Maurice Williams down in South Carolina while I was still in the service.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, once you got out of the service, you went back to Detroit, playing in the clubs and things like that... Set the scene for us â what was the environment like? Detroit being the city where the motor industry is based, a working-class blue-collar city, where people would cut loose after working in the plants all day.

Dennis Coffey

Detroit still is a music town. I still play one night a month at Bakerâs Keyboard Lounge, which is a jazz club that has been in existence for 74 years. We never rehearse, we never plan, I count off a couple of chords and we run with it. Which means every time we play stuff itâs different, which is a good thing for me. But when I got out of the service, I was out of the army for two weeks, I auditioned for a band gig, got the gig, and I was working six nights a week from that point on. Detroit at that time had a lot of bars, a lot of music and a lot of people supporting the music. Right now, the city is going through some economic woes but you can still hear live music all over the city. Itâs always been a great place to learn how to play, get your chops together and the people like it. You can still go out in Detroit and hear live music all the time.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

And still a lot of young musicians, too, coming up.

Dennis Coffey

Absolutely. I have some young cats in my band, theyâre in their 20s and 30s, and we have fun.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Who were some of the musicians you would see around in the â60s, performing in bars?

Dennis Coffey

There was one guy who performed with me in the Funk Brothers is Bob Babbitt, the bass player, and he and I used to do all the early â60s stuff, the Motown stuff. We played in clubs together too. There were different musicians, Bob Seger came up through the ranks playing clubs at a young age, plus you had the whole soul thing going on there too.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Before we jump ahead too much, explain the whole soul scene in Detroit at the time. On one of your early sessions, you met someone who had a little something to do with Motown. So, just explain what that whole environment was like.

Dennis Coffey

Well, I was 16 and had this partner who was 16, and we were doing rockabilly, he wrote the Elvis-type song called âCrazy Little Satellite,â and we cut a demo at Fortune Records. Somehow, Jackie Wilsonâs manager Nat Tarnopol heard that demo, so I found myself in the studio at 16, trying to be an artist with my partner, and Berry Gordy was the arranger â this was even before Motown. We cut the song, it didnât come out, and after six months we got impatient and demanded our contract back. And thatâs the end of it, I donât know what happened to that record.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

But in the wake of Motown starting â Berry Gordy being its founder â I guess, in addition to Motown doing its thing, there were a lot of labels and studios popping up in Detroit, trying to ride that wave of popularity.

Dennis Coffey

There were studios popping up on every corner, studios in the back of record shops, all over the place. We were doing sessions one after another, getting paid cash. Life was good, we were working all the time just making records.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

What was your ambition at that point? Did you want to be a performer on your own, a soloist, work with a group, or were you happy just going night to night and seeing what was coming to you?

Dennis Coffey

I always liked to practice and write songs, and one day I woke up and thought, âPeople are actually paying me to play music.â Because I used to play gigs for nothing in the beginning. The lights went on and I thought, âThis is great, I actually get paid for this,â and it just kept going. I never got up one day and thought I want to make a living as a musician, because I just never thought it would happen. So, as it started happening I just got busier and busier. In Detroit, a recording session is usually three hours, and we had to walk in at Motown or Golden World or wherever and put up some sheet music. You had to play that song in that hour, read the chart, come up with some ideas and make it a hit. There were three hours a session, I was doing 18 sessions a week, so figure it out â I was involved in about 50 songs every week for a long period of time. I could look on the Billboard charts and for one year solid I was on at least 10 songs in the top 100 and at least three in the top 10, for one year straight. We were very busy.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Explain what Golden World was.

Dennis Coffey

Golden World was a studio on Davidson started by Ed Wingate. We were never quite sure where he got the money, but I think he had a numbers-running business under the table. Whenever he had distribution problems, he would send out a couple of his guys and they always got paid. He seemed to have a lot of money. That was the Golden World era, weâd record there all the time with JJ Barnes and Edwin Starr and all the different acts there, all soul singers.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

And that was before you got down with Motown that you were doing stuff with Golden World?

Dennis Coffey

Golden World and a lot of different labels. We did a thing with The Parliaments, with George Clinton, âI Wanna Testify,â that kind of stuff; âOpen The Door To Your Heartâ with Darrell Banks, Betty LaVette, all kinds of things were happening even before Golden World and Motown, there were always different sessions going on.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

These were all â60s soul records made in Detroit, with a Motown-type of feel. Later on, you found a lot of these obscure records had found a whole new audience with the Northern soul scene.

Dennis Coffey

The Northern Soul scene... I put out a book over in Europe called Guitars, Bars and Motown Superstars, I went over there for nine days and people coming up to me who knew more details about the records Iâd done than I did. They were coming up to me with mint copies of records Iâd done that I didnât even have copies of. They were avid collectors, they knew their stuff, they knew their music.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Does everyone know what Northern Soul is? Not everybody. Northern Soul is basically records that sound like Motown records, made at the same time, but that werenât commercial successes, so they faded into obscurity. But in the early â70s in the north of England, soul collectors and DJs found these records and championed them at all-nighters, which are parties that went on all night, as you might guess. It kind of pre-dates all the rave culture in a funny way that came afterwards. But you played on a bunch of them and were surprised to find they were actually very popular, even though they were nobodies in terms of their success.

Dennis Coffey

I played on some of the records and then I went to a couple of some of the soul clubs that were playing Northern Soul and I did a weekend at a resort called Cleethorpes, where I rehearsed with a band in London â I was opening act for The Velvelettes. Theyâre like maniacs [in the UK]. They partied all night and dance to this music. It was great.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, at this time, for a session player in Detroit, getting down with Motown was something what everyone wanted to do?

Dennis Coffey

The Funk Brothers was the epitome of the best band in the world. My opinion of it was that I wouldnât have a chance of getting on there, so I never bothered with it. But I got a call one day from James Jamerson, the bass player, he introduced me to Hank Cosby, who was Stevie Wonderâs producer. They said they were doing this producersâ workshop upstairs at Golden World, because by then Motown had purchased it, and they wanted me to be part of the rhythm section. We were going to provide somewhere for the producers to get some of their ideas and have more time, as opposed to the studio time.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Because they were so rushed in the studio?

Dennis Coffey

Maybe for them, not for us, we were used to it. But for someone who didnât have a hit, maybe theyâre saying, âWhy donât you have a hit?â So, we started two-and-a-half hours a night, four nights a week, and within a few weeks Norman Whitfield, the producer, came in with this song âCloud Nineâ, and by that time I was playing funk in the clubs and I had wah-wah pedals, and distortion and all the effects. So, I pulled out the wah-wah pedal and played it on âCloud Nineâ and within two weeks I was in the studio recording it. All that effects stuff on all The Temptations records, thatâs me doing all that.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So that was your first session at Motown, letâs hear a bit of that.

(music: The Temptations â âCloud Nineâ / applause)

Dennis Coffey

Thank you. That was the Funk Brothers. You donât get any better than that. I canât even count how many millions of records we sold over at that place. They were the cats. Over in that room we all did that at the same time â that whole rhythm section was all of us playing together. That was about as good as it gets, at least to my mind.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

And that session, too, was a change of pace in a lot of ways, not only for the style of music, which was a lot funkier than what Motown was normally doing, but also the drummers. Can you explain what was going on there?

Dennis Coffey

That was one of the first sessions... At the workshop, we had a drummer called Spider Webb, he came up with that cymbal figure. The first drummer at Motown was Benny Benjamin, but by the time I got there it was Uriel Jones and Pistol. So, on that first session it was Spider Webb doing the cymbal part, and Iâm not sure if it was Uriel or Pistol doing the backbeat and the foot. From then on, most of the sessions I was doing with The Temptations, one drummer would play the fancy hi-hat and another would do the kick drum and the snare. Thatâs how you got that powerhouse. Then you had Eddie âBongoâ Brown on congas, thatâs how you got that polyrhythm thing, and Jack Ashford doing the hi and tambourine. Then you had James Jamerson doing the funky bottom, and Earl Van Dyke laying those big fat chords and the organ player Johnny Griffith. Then there was myself and usually Eddie Willis, from Mississippi, playing those funky things while Iâm doing something psychedelic. Then we had Robert White on guitar or Joe Messina doing the backbeat â he had a Fender. But those rhythm sections were all cut at the same time, so we played off each other and the track itself was better than any one of us because it was us collectively us jamming together, it was great.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

But what about the wah-wah on there? Talk a bit about that, because before this The Temptations had been doing pretty straight Motown stuff, the classic Motown sound. But this was more influenced by Sly Stone and a lot more funky stuff.

Dennis Coffey

The producer, Norman Whitfield, was listening to the psychedelic sound, Sly & the Family Stone and other groups, including the English groups. He wanted to take it in a different direction, this was protest time and in Detroit weâd had the riots. Someone came in the studio and said someone had just firebombed the drugstore down the street, and it was in flames. We had one person watching the flames while we tried to finish the record, and we got it done, finished up, took the tapes and left. But it was very tense in those days, and Norman brought that to the music, because Motown was love songs. But he brought the protest element to it and he saw me as someone to make it happen, with the distortion pedals and the funk and the wah-wah stuff and the Echoplex, and all that texture could add to what he was trying to achieve.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Do you want to give us a little demo of that stuff, because Norman didnât have the idea of adding the wah-wah element to the song â he just had you do your thing, right?

Dennis Coffey

We made up stuff as we went along.

(music: Dennis Coffey â guitar demo / applause)

Thatâs the wah-wah pedal, now Iâll show a bit of distortion.

(music: Dennis Coffey â guitar demo)

And you can add effects to it like in âBall of Confusion.â

(music: Dennis Coffey â guitar demo)

I combined all this with other devices, so Norman would say, âLet me see your bag of toys, letâs see what youâve got.â So, Iâd pull out all these pedals and heâd say, âI like that one.â And weâre off and running.

[Applause]

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, Iâm curious to know for you as a session player, how much of it was an assembly line, a type of tunnel-vision mentality, and how much were you aware of the songs you were playing and the impact they might have?

Dennis Coffey

Motown would have a master rhythm chart with three different lines: the piano part, the bass part and maybe a third part in there. The rhythm section would all get the same chart, and weâd play the chart. What we would do is play the chart, but my job was to maybe like [provide] the intro on âJust My Imaginationâ â that was mine, I made that up. And at the end you might hear a solo or a figure, which Iâd made up. We also got good at playing fill-inâs, which we played on the offbeat, so we wouldnât interfere with the singer, because we had no idea what the singer would be singing. We got very good at doing little fill-in parts that wouldnât overpower anyone, so thatâs how we did it.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, you had no idea of what track you were doing for what singer?

Dennis Coffey

Sometimes they had the name of the track on there, sometimes they had the artists, sometimes they didnât. But we never heard it until they came in. I remember when we did âStill Waters Run Deepâ with The Four Tops, to me it sounded backwards when we played it, but once it was a finished record it sounded great and ended up being a hit. We didnât know that at the time.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Is there something else from this Temptations era you want to throw on?

Dennis Coffey

This is the intro with the Echoplex and the Fuzz,

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

âBall Of Confusion,â The Temptations.

(music: The Temptations â âBall of Confusionâ / applause)

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, you werenât exclusive to Motown, but others were, right?

Dennis Coffey

Most of the Funk Brothers were signed exclusively to Motown and they couldnât work for anybody else. I remember doing a session with the Funk Brothers at 4 AM on a Sunday at United Sound, and itâs raining and cold and dark out, and there was a knock on the back door. We opened it up expecting it to be a musician and it was Ralph Seltzer, Berry Gordyâs hatchet man, and he runs in, points at Willis and Jamerson and said, âI see you,â and runs back out the door. They got fined over that, but they couldnât do anything to me.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, the Funk Brothers, who were under contract to Motown, if they got caught they got fined for doing outside sessions?

Dennis Coffey

Yes, and on rare occasions they got fired for a short time.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

But you avoided all that.

Dennis Coffey

I considered myself a free agent. I almost signed to Motown as an artist. I did a record called âItâs Your Thingâ and gave a copy to Clarence Avant at Sussex Records, a copy to Hank Cosby to give to Berry. Within a month I had a signed contract to Sussex Records as an artist, then Hank comes up to me and says, âBerry loves that record, he wants to sign it.â Too late, thatâs the deal.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, at that point youâre doing stuff with Sussex and you were working with Mike Theodore at that time?

Dennis Coffey

He was my partner playing in a jazz club three nights a week after doing all the sessions with the Lyman Woodard group. Mike and I ran into each other at Golden World, he was an arranger, I was an arranger. The way he learned to produce was a friend of ours owned Tera-Shirma Studio, and he gave us the keys to the studio, because Mike Theodore was engineering and I was doing the production and arranging. Weâd bring in these bands from the clubs we knew and weâd record them at about 3 AM, when the studio wasnât busy. Thatâs how we learned how to produce. One of the first groups we did was Rare Earth, we did an album with them on MGM, and that was the beginning. When I first met Mike, Steve Mancha had this session with Scepter and he wanted Mike to do the charts. Mike had this big budget to do horns and strings, and Iâd had my first string day with The Holidays the week before, so he said, âI notice you can do violins, I can do horn and rhythm, but Iâve never done strings before, so letâs partner up on this arrangement.â I said to myself, âIâve done them once, that makes me an expert.â So away we went.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

How did you go from doing the productions for other people with Mike to doing your own solo recordings?

Dennis Coffey

We signed up as house producers for Sussex. I took the Lyman Woodard Trio and did an album with them for MGM, because Clarence okayed it once heâd heard the demo. That album was the first I did, but they didnât promote the album because the label, Clarence, had went under. So, he came back with this new label, Sussex, and gave me the money to cut the Evolution album.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, you put this solo album out and what happened?

Dennis Coffey

For the first year, nothing. I thought, âThis is great. Iâm trying to get something going and nothingâs happening.â I did another album with a guitar band, I used the Funk Brothers, and then I wrote out horn parts for guitarists and I brought in Ray Monette from Rare Earth, myself and Joe Podorsek and we had nine guitarists playing the melody to âScorpio.â In the year nothing happened, I did another album called Goinâ for Myself and used horns and strings instead. Before that album could be released, Ron Moseley, the national promotions guy in New York, called me on the phone and said, âMan, Iâm going to all the clubs and theyâre going crazy over Scorpio. Itâs tearing the roof off, so weâre going to stop this album and re-service Scorpio.â I remember I was sitting in a bar in Detroit with Mike, the record was number 13 and the next week weâre listening, theyâre going up the charts, nothing â I thought it had fallen off â but it went from 13 to number one in one week.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, this was a year after you put the album out, and you thought it was dead in the water?

Dennis Coffey

It sat there and did nothing for a year.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, this is what revived that album.

(music: Dennis Coffey â âScorpioâ /applause)

Dennis Coffey

Thank you. If you hear all the guys yelling in the background, thatâs Jack Ashford and Bongo Eddie, they always went crazy. I left the mics on and Theodore said, âWeâve got to keep that,â so we left it in.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, you wrote the guitar parts as horn parts, basically?

Dennis Coffey

Yeah, Mike and I were doing a lot of horn and string arranging with the rhythm section and we were getting so jaded that weâd look in the union book and find some instrument, and if someone knew how to play it, weâd bring them down and use it.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, thatâs basically nine guitars doing the melody?

Dennis Coffey

Yes, then I did a baritone sax part through my wah-wah and my bass to add another piece to it, so itâs like a guitar orchestra.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, you get that wall of sound with the melody. But you couldnât recreate that live when you went and toured to support the albumâ¦

Dennis Coffey

It was too expensive. To fly all those guys around the country, no oneâs going to pay you to do that, unless youâre one of the big superstars.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

But that song was still pretty huge for you.

Dennis Coffey

Over a million sold, and people still want to hear it today. We still do it, but we donât do it like it is on the record, we change it every time and just get wild with it.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

I guess, the breakdowns in a lot of these tracks from that period are what has sustained them for a whole new audience. Obviously, they were sampled in the late â80s and â90s, but they were also played in the hip-hop park jams in the Bronx, by DJs who were just spinning back the breakdowns.

Dennis Coffey

I think thatâs what broke âScorpio,â and a lot of my records. I had the guitar parts out in the open â they could grab it, sample it and then loop it, make other records around it. The first time I went to New York, in this big hotel in Brooklyn... Iâm not saying it was rough but we went in this place and I asked the manager, âWhere do we park, whereâs your parking lot guy?â He said, âTo tell the truth, our parking guy was shot last night, so we donât have one. Drive around to the parking lot, back your truck up against the wall, take your distributor cap off and chain down your steering wheel and youâll be OK.â Anyway, weâre playing to 2,000 people in this big ballroom, itâs jammed, and we do âScorpio,â and I look up during the percussion break and there are 2,000 people in a conga line coming towards the bandstand. It freaked me out, it was wild.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, youâre doing the solo records, youâre on Sussex. Youâre not doing the Motown stuff at this point, or are you?

Dennis Coffey

I was working out at Mowest. Why not? They were paying me scale-and-a-half, and I still did the Motown stuff, and I worked with Ringo Starr, Quincy Jones, Tom Jones, everyone in the S.W.A.T. TV show and, in concert, everything that LA had to offer.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Letâs back up a bit, you moved out to L.A. What was the motivation for that?

Dennis Coffey

Things were getting slow in Detroit and I wanted to move somewhere that had more action. The Motown thing was slowing down and there werenât a lot of labels in Detroit like there used to be, so I moved to LA to see what opportunities were out there. And I wanted to do a film â I thought that was a big deal. When I got there, I told Clarence Avant to see if he could find me a deal to do a film, and I was sitting out there for two months, and didnât hear anything, so I thought, âOK, weâre falling off a cliff here, weâre done.â So, I get a call from Motown, and I went into the studio at Mowest at 10 AM, and they kept bouncing me upstairs, downstairs. By the time Iâd finished recording everything they needed doing it was 4 AM the following day, that was my first session at Mowest.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

That was Motownâs West Coast studios, but Motown actually left Detroit altogether around that time.

Dennis Coffey

They had their other studio ready, and then one day the Funk Brothers turned up for a session... Here you come, youâve spent the major part of your career doing sessions for Motown, you show up to do a session, and thereâs a sign on the door saying: âThere will never be any sessions here again. Weâre closed.â Thatâs the word to the Funk Brothers got on their final day. They turned up expecting to do a session, and to get paid, and thereâs a sign on the door saying Motown is closed in Detroit.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

Thatâs pretty crazy. What was the reaction of the guys who you stayed in touch with?

Dennis Coffey

Has anyone seen the Standing in the Shadows of Motown documentary? That pretty much sums it up. The guy who made it, Allan Slutsky, wanted me to do more in the film. He said, âLet me see your guitar, I want to show you how I want you to play it.â I said, âOK.â So, when it came to the show I said, âAlan, why donât you play it yourself?â and I didnât go. But the guys felt bad about what happened â he just rubbed me the wrong way â but all the guys felt let down and about four weeks later I was at the R&B Foundation in Philly and Chaka Khan and Aretha [Franklin] and Jerry Butler, everyone was there, Bonnie Raitt, and they gave myself, Uriel Jones, Eddie Willis and Bob Babbitt â pioneer Funk Brother â awards, it was really nice. Dionne Warwick was singing there, everyone in R&B was performing. So, it was a great wrap-up to the whole career of working with the Funk Brothers.

Jeff âChairmanâ Mao

So, you went to LA to try and get some TV and soundtrack work. As far as âScorpio,â and that whole era, you did the whole guitar orchestra thing, but when you had a chance to do film work, you experimented with that as wellâ¦

Dennis Coffey

I always try to do different things, itâs the heart of creativity. I always try to play new songs, try new licks, always something new. If you donât, it can get boring, youâve got to challenge yourself all the time. So, I went to see Fred Weintraub, who was doing this movie Black Belt Jones, and he had everything except a main theme and a love theme. So, I sat down and decided Iâve got to do something different. I watched it and came up with the main theme and the love theme.
